title: Sh. Bhagwant Singh vs Sh. Vikas Chadha on 16 April, 2013
doc:
Sh. Bhagwant Singh vs Sh. Vikas Chadha on 16 April, 2013

               IN THE COURT OF SH. SONU AGNIHOTRI,
        ADDL. SENIOR CIVIL JUDGE-CUM- JUDGE SMALL CAUSE
                   COURT-CUM- GUARDIAN JUDGE,
                    DISTRICT: SOUTH, NEW DELHI.


   MCA No. 09/13
   UNIQUE ID NO. 02406C0059002013


   SH. BHAGWANT SINGH,
   S/o Late Shri Gurdial Singh,
   R/o 51, Church Road,
   Bhogal, New Delhi.                                      ..........Appellant.

                                       Vs.

   SH. VIKAS CHADHA,
   S/o Late Shri Om Prakash Chadha,
   R/o 51, Masjid Road,
   Jungpura, Bhogal, New Delhi.                          ........Respondent.


       DATE OF INSTITUTION                     : 20.02.2013
       DATE OF RESERVING ORDER                 : 06.04.2013
       DATE OF PRONOUNCEMENT                   : 16.04.2013

                                O R D E R

16.04.2013 Vide this order, I shall dispose of appeal filed by appellant under Order 43 Rule 1(r) read with Section 151 CPC against order dated 18.02.2013 passed by Court of Ms. Ritu Singh, Ld. Civil Judge-IV, Saket Courts, New Delhi in Civil Suit No. 66/13.

MCA No. 09/13 Page No. 1 of 15

Relevant facts for disposal of the present appeal are as follows:-

1. In the appeal brief facts of the case have been mentioned by appellant. It is pertinent to mention that appellant is plaintiff in civil suit filed before trial court and respondent herein is defendant therein. In the suit filed by appellant, it is stated that he purchased back side basement of property bearing no. 49, Khasra No. 898/567, Khatauni No. 168 of Mauja Aliganj situated at Maszid Road, Jangpura, Bhogal, New Delhi (hereinafter referred to as 'Suit Property') from father of respondent vide registered sale deed dated 26.06.2000. It is stated that father of respondent Sh. Om Prakash Chadha sold suit property to appellant with common passage in the basement measuring 3 Â¼' wide alongwith all rights, superstructure built up therein. It is stated that respondent is owner of property bearing no. 49 (front side of property) part of khasra no. 898/567 of Mauja Aliganj, Maszid Road, Jangpura, Bhogal, New Delhi and has a common wall with suit property of appellant having a ventilator on it after death of his father.
2. It is stated that appellant runs a business of repairing of electrical home appliances from suit property for the last 22 years. It is stated that appellant alongwith father of respondent got built a common toilet in the said property towards the right MCA No. 09/13 Page No. 2 of 15 side from entrance of suit property having a common passage after purchase of suit property. It is stated that appellant also shared cost incurred towards building of the said toilet. It is stated that after death of his father, respondent started harassing appellant on one pretext or the other.
3. It is stated that in the suit property, there is a ventilator at the left side of suit property which was also got closed by the acts of respondent as he did not allow appellant to use common passage in the toilet and was obstructing common passage, common toilet and use of the ventilator.
4. It is stated that there is a main gate outside the said premises comprising of basement no. 49 and 51 and respondent closes the gate from 10.00 pm to 7.00 am in the morning. It is stated that being lawful owner of suit property, appellant should have all the rights to enter suit property between 10.00 pm to 7.00 am.
5. It is stated that on 23.12.2012, when appellant was going to use the common toilet, respondent did not allow appellant to use the same and obstructed his way, caught hold of him and bet him mercilessly and FIR No. 449 dated 23.12.2012 has been lodged in this regard. It is stated that on 05.02.2013, MCA No. 09/13 Page No. 3 of 15 respondent again started harassing appellant as now he is trying to wrongfully close/block a common ventilator of the suit property which is adjacent to basement. It is stated that respondent has started closing the ventilator by fixing wooden structure and grills on account of which cracks in the suit property have appeared which may damage suit property. It is stated that appellant lodged complaint in this regard with police and MCD.
6. In his application under Order 39 Rule 1 & 2 read with Section 151 CPC, appellant prayed for passing ex-parte injunction order thereby restraining respondent, his servants, agents, employees or any one acting on behalf of respondent to stop closing/blocking ventilation system of appellant. Appellant further sought relief of restraining respondent, his servants, agents, employees or any one acting on behalf of respondent to obstruct ingress and outgress of appellant/his family members/employees from the suit property. Appellant further prayed for restraining respondent from interfering appellant/his family and staff to use the toilet without obstruction.
7. In the grounds of appeal, appellant has stated that Ld. Trial Court failed to appreciate that appellant being lawful and absolute owner of suit property has every right to access to his MCA No. 09/13 Page No. 4 of 15 property at any time during day or night. It is stated that respondent is restraining appellant/his family members from ingress and egress to suit property. It is stated that if interim injunction is not granted, appellant would be deprived of his legal right to use suit property at his will despite being lawful owner thereof.
8. It is stated that Ld. Trial Court failed to appreciate that FIR under Section 323/341/34 IPC has already been registered and there is likelihood that similar incident may again take place as at present respondent has closed 7 out of 10 windows of ventilators. It is stated that Ld. Trial Court gravely erred in holding that allowing the interim application would tantamount to decreeing the suit. Law laid down by Hon'ble Supreme Court of India in case titled as 'Deoraj Vs. State of Maharashtra & Ors.

AIR 2004 SC 1975' has been mentioned by appellant in appeal. It has been laid down as under by Hon'ble Apex Court :

"Situations emerge where the granting of an interim relief would tantamount to granting the final relief itself. And then there may be converse cases where withholding of an interim relief would tantamount to dismissal of main petition itself; for, by the time main matter comes up for hearing there MCA No. 09/13 Page No. 5 of 15 would be nothing left to be allowed as relief to the petitioner thought all the findings may be in his favour. In such cases the availability of a very strong prima facie case of a standard much higher than just prima facie case, the considerations of balance of convenience and irreparable injury forcefully titling the balance of case totally in favour of the applicant may persuade the Court to grant an interim relief through it amounts to granting the final relief itself. Of course, such would be rare and exceptional cases. The Court would grant such an interim relief only if satisfied that withholding of it would prick the conscience of the Court and do violence to the sese of justice, resulting in injustice being perpetuated throughout the hearing, and at the end the Court would not be able to vindicate the cause of justice. Obviously such would be rare cases accompanied by compelling circumstances, where the injury complained of is immediate and pressing and would cause extreme hardship. The conduct of the parties shall also have to be seen and the Court may put the parties on such terms as may be prudent"
MCA No. 09/13 Page No. 6 of 15

It is stated that withholding of interim relief would do violence to sense of justice, result in injustice which would perpetuate throughout the hearing and at the end, Court would not be able to vindicate cause of justice.

9. It is stated that respondent refused to accept summons and did not appear before Ld. Trial Court for defending the suit. It is stated that suit deserved to be heard ex-parte under Order 9 Rule 6 1 (a) CPC but that Trial Court posted the matter for further consideration on 03.04.2013 whereas an order to proceed ex-parte should have been passed by Ld. Trial Court. Appellant has mentioned law laid down by Hon'ble Supreme Court of India in case titled as 'Wander Ltd. Vs. Antox India (P) Ltd. 1990 Suppl. 1 SCC 727 (Para no. 5)'.

10. Appellant has prayed for setting aside impugned order dated 18.02.2013 and for passing any other order which this Court may deem fit.

11. Respondent did not put up an appearance before Ld. Trial Court even after his service through his wife by way of refusal and application of appellant under Order 39 Rule 1 & 2 CPC was decided by Ld. Trial Court after listening to arguments addressed on behalf of appellant.

MCA No. 09/13 Page No. 7 of 15

12. I have heard arguments addressed on appeal and perused the record including Trial Court Record and judgments filed on behalf of both appellant and respondent.

13. Ld. Trial Court vide order dated 18.02.2013 dismissed application under Order 39 Rule 1 & 2 CPC filed by appellant. Ld. Trial Court in order dated 18.02.2013 observed that the reliefs claimed in the application are the same as those claimed in the main suit and therefore allowing the application would tantamount to decreeing of suit at preliminary stage without trial of suit on merits. Ld. Trial Court further observed that moreover, no exceptional ground has been shown to exist by plaintiff in his favour for granting main relief sought in the suit at interim stage. With these observations, application of appellant was dismissed.

14. Appellant did not press his prayer seeking restraining respondent from interfering appellant/his family and staff to use the toilet without any obstruction at the stage of interim application and separate statement of appellant in this regard was recorded by Ld. Trial Court. So, I will not be passing any order in regard to this prayer of appellant as when the same has not been pressed before Ld. Trial Court, the same cannot be agitated by appellant in appeal.

MCA No. 09/13 Page No. 8 of 15

15. Earlier after listening to the arguments on appeal, matter was listed for Orders on Appeal on 25.03.2013 but that on 22.03.2013, appellant filed an affidavit under Order 19 Rule 1 CPC alongwith certain documents and notice of the affidavit was ordered to be issued to respondent thereupon. Arguments on affidavit of appellant under Order 19 Rule 1 CPC were heard.

16. In affidavit under Order 19 Rule 1 CPC, appellant has mentioned judgment of Hon'ble Supreme Court of India in case titled as 'Ramesh Kumar Vs. Kesho Ram AIR 1992 SC 700' in which Hon'ble Supreme Court of India held that "when subsequent events are pleaded in the course of an appeal or proceedings of revision, the Court may, having regard to the nature of allegations of fact on which the plea is based, permit evidence to be adduced by means of affidavits as envisaged in Rule 1 of Order 19 CPC.........". In affidavit filed by appellant under Order 19 Rule 1 CPC, appellant has mentioned that appellant purchased suit property on 26.06.2000 and prior to its purchase, appellant was a tenant in suit property and using the same since year 1991. Appellant has annexed copy of rent receipt in this regard alongwith his affidavit. Appellant has further mentioned in the affidavit that father of respondent received Rs.40,000/- from him as Pagrdi on 14.04.1992 with regard to suit property and has filed receipt in this regard MCA No. 09/13 Page No. 9 of 15 alongwith affidavit. Appellant has mentioned in the affidavit that he purchased portable Genset on the same address on 19.07.1993 (copy of bill annexed). Appellant has further mentioned that sales tax number has been allotted by sales tax department w.e.f. 15.04.1994 (photocopy of Form ST-8 filed by appellant with affidavit). During course of arguments, counsel for appellant was inquired about purpose of filing of this affidavit by appellant to which counsel for appellant submitted that the same has been filed by appellant in order to show that appellant is in possession of suit property since 1991 and that ventilator in the suit property is existing since then. First of all, let me make it clear that documents filed by appellant alongwith his affidavit are not the documents which show any subsequent event. These documents were very much in possession of appellant even at the time when he filed suit. Appellant should have filed the same alongwith suit. Further all these documents if taken into account merely prima facie show that appellant might be in possession of suit property since year 1992. All these documents do not show that ventilator on common wall of suit property as well as property of respondent existed since year 1992. Counsel for appellant during course of arguments submitted that appellant is claiming relief with regard to ventilator on the ground of acquiring easementry rights by appellant for more than 20 years with regard to air which appellant has been using from ventilator MCA No. 09/13 Page No. 10 of 15 since last more than 20 years without interruption. Appellant in para no. 2 of plaint filed by him before Ld. Trial Court has mentioned that defendant/respondent is owner of property bearing MCD No. 49 (Front side of the property) part of Khasra No. 898/567 of Mauja Aliganj, Masjid Road, Jangpura, Bhogal, New Delhi and has a common wall to the suit property of plaintiff/appellant having a ventilator on it after death of his father. As per pleadings of appellant himself in the plaint filed by him, ventilator on the common wall was created/made after death of father of defendant/respondent. As per pleadings of appellant, appellant purchased suit property from father of respondent on 26.06.2000 meaning thereby that father of respondent was alive on 26.06.2000 and must have been remained alive thereafter till his death. In any eventuality, as per pleadings of appellant himself, ventilator was created/made on common wall after death of father of defendant/respondent and in these circumstances, it cannot be said at this stage that appellant was/is using ventilator for air for last more than 20 years uninterruptedly. Further even if, this pleading of appellant is ignored, appellant has not annexed any document which can show that ventilator existed in the common wall of suit property and property of respondent since 1991/92 i.e. for more than 20 years on basis of which he is claiming easementry right. Further ventilator admittedly is on common wall of property of appellant MCA No. 09/13 Page No. 11 of 15 and respondent meaning thereby that both appellant as well as respondent may peep into property of each other. In 'Abk Prasad Vs. Union of India & Others in WP No. 860 of 1999 and 13959 of 1996 and Tr. Cr. L. MP 2213 of 1999 (Date of decision:25.01.2002)', Hon'ble High Court Andhra Pradesh has held that " Any right to privacy must encompass and protect the personal intimacies of the home, the family, marriage, motherhood, procreation and child-rearing". Though suit property admittedly is being used commercially by appellant and respondent also has given on rent his part of basement (during course of arguments, respondent submitted that he has given his part of basement on rent for commercial use), still, I am of the opinion that both the parties have their respective rights of privacy and at this stage, respondent cannot be restrained from closing/blocking ventilation system of appellant particularly in the circumstances when admittedly appellant has one more ventilator towards common passage which though admittedly at the moment lying closed but can always be opened (as per counsel for appellant during course of arguments, the same was closed as drainage water used to enter from that ventilator. I am of the opinion that drainage problem can always be sorted out by making some arrangement in this regard and right to privacy which has even been recognized by Hon'ble Apex Court in various judgments as part of Article 21 of The Constitution of MCA No. 09/13 Page No. 12 of 15 India has primacy over easementry right which also in the circumstances of present case at this stage does not seem to be existing.). Reasoning given by Ld. Trial Court in these circumstances is not relevant to be discussed so far as this relief sought by appellant is concerned.

17. Appellant has referred to judgment of Hon'ble Supreme Court of India in case titled as 'Deoraj Vs. State of Maharashtra (Supra)'. No WS has been filed by respondent till hearing of arguments of present appeal as apparent from TCR. Though respondent during course of arguments did not admit ownership of appellant with regard to suit property, still on the basis of copy of sell deed filed by appellant, prima facie, appellant appears to be owner of suit property. A person having ownership of a property normally should have access to his property at any time during course of the day. Any restriction on his movement to enter into his property may in a given set of circumstances amount to wrongful restraint. Counsel for respondent during course of arguments admitted that respondent puts a lock on gate from 10.00 pm to 7.00 am in the morning. Respondent when inquired during course of arguments regarding the same, respondent submitted that he locks the gate for safety purpose as he alongwith his family resides on upper portion of basement. It has not been disputed that the gate MCA No. 09/13 Page No. 13 of 15 which is locked by respondent during night is only way to go to suit property and there is no other way to go to suit property. To my mind, Ld. Trial Court wrongly appreciated facts in this regard and held that allowing the application would tantamount to decreeing the suit at preliminary stage without trial of suit on merits. Ld. Trial Court wrongly appreciated and observed that no exceptional ground has been shown to exist by plaintiff/appellant in his favour for granting main relief sought in the suit at interim stage. As per judgment of Hon'ble Apex Court in Deoraj's Case (Supra), the availability of a very strong prima facie case of a standard much higher than just prima facie case, the considerations of balance of convenience and irreparable injury forcefully tilting balance of case totally in favour of applicant may persuade the Court to grant an interim relief though it amounts to granting of final relief itself. Applying ratio of this case to facts of present case, I am of the opinion that appellant has prima facie shown ownership of suit property and being owner of suit property, appellant has strong prima facie right to enter into his property at any juncture of time. Balance of convenience lies in favour of appellant as a person has every right to enter into his property at any point of time. Irreparable injury shall be caused to appellant which cannot be compensated in terms of money by restricting his movement to enter into his property. Therefore I hold that order of Ld. Trial MCA No. 09/13 Page No. 14 of 15 Court to this relief sought by appellant is not sustainable in law and is accordingly set aside. Exceptional circumstances have been shown to exist in favour of appellant as movement of a person to go into his property cannot be restricted by a private person, State though in certain circumstances may curtail right of movement of a person. Respondent / agent / servants / employees or any one acting on behalf of respondent is restrained from obstructing ingress and egress of appellant and his family members/employees in suit property till disposal of suit. Keeping in mind security aspect as agitated on behalf of respondent, a solution to this problem may be respondent giving a duplicate key of the lock of the gate to appellant. With these observations, appeal filed by appellant is partly allowed and partly dismissed. Let TCR be sent back to Trial Court with copy of the Order.

File be consigned to Record Room.

Announced in open Court on 16.04.2013 Sonu Agnihotri JSCC-cum-ASCJ-cum-GJ South District, Saket Courts, New Delhi.

MCA No. 09/13 Page No. 15 of 15
